item.title: Palabra del día en inglés: ‘revitalize’
item.description: Esta palabra ha aparecido en 228 artículos en NYTimes.com en el último año. ¿Puedes usarla en una frase?
item.dc:creator: The Learning Network

item.title: Word of the Day: revitalize
item.description: This word has appeared in 228 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
item.dc:creator: The Learning Network

item.title: Operator Who Crashed Ferry Off South Korea Was Looking at His Phone
item.description: The operator and two other officers were charged with gross negligence after the ferry ran aground on Wednesday carrying 267 people.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon

media:content.media:credit: The Korea Coast Guard/Yonhap, via Associated Press
media:content.media:description: The Queen Jenuvia II was carrying 267 people when it crashed into a rocky islet off South Korea on Wednesday night.

item.title: Ex-Mayor Is Sentenced to Life for Human Trafficking Tied to Southeast Asia Scam Centers
item.description: A court in the Philippines convicted Alice Guo for trafficking people to a compound that officials have linked to online scams and organized crime.
item.dc:creator: Francesca Regalado
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

media:content.media:credit: Jam Sta Rosa/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Alice Guo, the former mayor of Bamban in the Philippines, during a Senate hearing in 2024.

item.title: El talento chino sigue impulsando el avance de la IA en Silicon Valley
item.description: Aunque algunos ejecutivos de California pintan a China como el enemigo, los profesionales del país asiático siguen desempeñando un papel importante en la investigación estadounidense.
item.dc:creator: Cade Metz and Eli Tan

media:content.media:credit: Jason Henry para The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Una nueva investigación muestra lo importante que sigue siendo el talento chino en ingeniería para las empresas de Silicon Valley.

item.title: Indonesia’s Mount Semeru Erupts and Rains Ash on Villages
item.description: Mount Semeru on the island of Java is one of the Indonesia’s most active volcanoes. Its latest eruption forced hundreds to flee their homes.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young and Muktita Suhartono

media:content.media:credit: Agus Harianto/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: A cloud of hot ash and smoke from the erupting Mount Semeru in Lumajang, East Java, Indonesia, on Wednesday.

item.title: Zelenski lidia con un caso de corrupción que afecta la unidad de Ucrania durante la guerra
item.description: Una investigación de gran escala sobre una trama multimillonaria de sobornos ha implicado a colaboradores cercanos al presidente Zelenski.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.category: Servant of the People (Ukrainian Political Party)

media:content.media:credit: Sergei Supinsky/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Volodímir Zelenski, presidente de Ucrania, el mes pasado en Kiev

item.title: Franco murió hace 50 años, pero sigue ganando adeptos en España
item.description: Los jóvenes españoles se sienten cada vez más atraídos por el dictador Francisco Franco. Por eso, el gobierno está diseñando aplicaciones, juegos y camisetas para promover la democracia.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz and Maria Contreras Coll

media:content.media:description: La tumba de Francisco Franco a las afueras de Madrid sigue atrayendo a dolientes, lo que revela las persistentes disputas en el seno de la sociedad española sobre el legado del dictador. José Luis Ortiz, partidario de Franco, cuida la tumba.

item.title: How Japan Is Tackling Its Bear Problem
item.description: Bear attacks are at record levels in Japan, with more than a dozen people killed this year. Javier C. Hernández, our Tokyo bureau chief, looks at the causes and how Japan is responding.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández, Nailah Morgan, Kiuko Notoya, Karen Hanley and Daishi Kusunoki

item.title: Franco Died 50 Years Ago, but He’s Still Winning New Fans in Spain
item.description: Young Spaniards are increasingly drawn to the dictator Francisco Franco. So the government is designing apps, games and T-shirts to promote democracy.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz and Maria Contreras Coll

media:content.media:description: Francisco Franco’s grave outside Madrid still draws mourners, highlighting lingering disputes within Spanish society over the dictator’s legacy. José Luis Ortiz, a Franco supporter, tends to the tomb.

item.title: La bodega neoyorquina, personaje entrañable de la ciudad
item.description: La icónica tienda de la esquina es quizá el símbolo definitivo de una ciudad en constante evolución y movimiento.
item.dc:creator: Anna Kodé

media:content.media:credit: Lanna Apisukh for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Bodegas may be the ultimate symbol of adaptability in an ever-changing city. A recent example: Bodega Comedy, which presents shows in corner stores around the city.

item.title: The Hunt Is On for Bears in Japan After Deadly Attacks
item.description: Residents in the northern region of Akita are living in fear after dozens of assaults on humans. Riot police and the army have been sent to help.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández, Kiuko Notoya and Kentaro Takahashi

media:content.media:credit: Kentaro Takahashi for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Matagi hunters Hideo Suzuki, left, and Masaru Ito, holding traditional hunting tools known as ”nagasa.”

item.title: Corrections: Nov. 20, 2025
item.description: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Nov. 20, 2025.

item.title: Quote of the Day: Not a Sanctuary, but Still a Border Patrol Target
item.description: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, November 20, 2025.

item.title: Top National Book Awards Go to Writing About the Middle East
item.description: Rabih Alameddine’s “The True True Story of Raja the Gullible (and His Mother)” won in fiction, while Omar El Akkad’s reckoning with Gaza took the nonfiction prize.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth A. Harris
item.category: The True True Story of Raja the Gullible (and His Mother) (Book)
One Day, Everyone Will Have Always Been Against This (Book)

media:content.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Omar El Akkad accepting the 2025 National Book Award for nonfiction on Wednesday night.

item.title: NYT Crossword Answers for Nov. 20, 2025
item.description: Adam Wagner loves crosswords as much as the next guy.
item.dc:creator: Sam Corbin

item.title: Trump and Mamdani Will Meet at White House on Friday
item.description: The meeting between Zohran Mamdani, the mayor-elect of New York City, and President Trump will come after the two men have fiercely attacked one another.
item.dc:creator: Emma G. Fitzsimmons

media:content.media:credit: Amir Hamja for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani said he wanted to speak plainly to the president. President Trump, in a social media post, called Mr. Mamdani a communist.

item.title: Saudi Arabia, Once Shunned, Has Corporate Titans Swooning for Deals
item.description: Some of the most prominent U.S. executives gathered at the Kennedy Center for an event promoting deal-making with the oil-rich kingdom.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hirsch
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts

media:content.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump posing next to Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia for a group photo at the U.S.-Saudi Investment Forum at the Kennedy Center in Washington.

item.title: House Votes to Kill Bill Allowing Senators to Sue Government
item.description: The measure has prompted a backlash, but the top Senate Republican appeared inclined to preserve it, arguing that it would protect the body against investigatory overreach.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson and Carl Hulse

media:content.media:credit: Anna Rose Layden for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Senator Lindsey Graham was one of eight Republican senators whose phone records were obtained as part of a special prosecutor’s investigation.

item.title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘Dating Straight Boys’
item.description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.

media:content.media:credit: Brian Rea

item.title: Florida Lawmaker Stole FEMA Funds for House Campaign, Prosecutors Say
item.description: Representative Sheila Cherfilus-McCormick misused $5 million in Covid-related funds during the pandemic in part to finance her campaign, according to the Justice Department.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Ziegler

media:content.media:credit: Tom Williams/CQ-Roll Call, Inc via Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Representative Sheila Cherfilus-McCormick has since 2022 represented a district that includes parts of Broward and Palm Beach Counties.

item.title: Nvidia Earnings Fuel Rally in Global Technology Stocks
item.description: The chipmaker’s profit surge and strong revenue forecast helped to ease fears that spending on A.I. infrastructure might be outpacing demand.
item.dc:creator: River Akira Davis and Joe Rennison
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

media:content.media:credit: Michael M. Santiago/Getty Images
media:content.media:description: A trader on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange on Wednesday. In the United States, Nvidia shares climbed more than 5 percent in after-hours trading.

item.title: Larry Summers to Stop Teaching at Harvard While It Investigates His Epstein Ties
item.description: The former Harvard president had previously stepped down from other positions following revelations about his longtime connections to Jeffrey Epstein.
item.dc:creator: Mark Arsenault and Mike Isaac

media:content.media:credit: Chitose Suzuki/Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Lawrence Summers at a commencement ceremony at Harvard University in Cambridge, Mass., in 2006.

item.title: Guinness Record for World’s Largest Afro Broken by Jessica Martinez
item.description: With an Afro that is more than six feet in circumference, Jessica Martinez set a new Guinness record.
item.dc:creator: Alisha Haridasani Gupta

item.title: México no solo es el principal proveedor de EE. UU. Ahora es su principal comprador
item.description: Por primera vez en al menos 30 años, Estados Unidos ha exportado más a México que a Canadá, según muestran datos del gobierno estadounidense, lo que constituye una señal de lo mucho que se ha consolidado el comercio norteamericano.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner

media:content.media:credit: Gabriel V. Cárdenas para The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Unos camiones trasladaban mercancías de Estados Unidos a México en febrero. “México es el principal socio de Estados Unidos”, dijo Marcelo Ebrard, secretario de Economía mexicano, en referencia a su relación comercial.

item.title: NASA Releases Images of Comet 3I/ATLAS Passing by Mars
item.description: With the government reopened, the space agency at last released pictures captured by a fleet of government spacecraft of an object that came from beyond our solar system.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang

media:content.media:credit: NASA/Lowell Observatory/Qicheng Zhang

item.title: Robert L. Stirm, Returning P.O.W. in Pulitzer-Winning Photo, Dies at 92
item.description: The image immortalized a Vietnam veteran’s joyous homecoming to his beaming family, but it hid the truth about an unraveling marriage.
item.dc:creator: Jeré Longman
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Sal Veder/Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Lt. Col. Robert L. Stirm on March 17, 1973, as he was greeted by his family at Travis Air Force Base in Fairfield, Calif., after five and a half years as a prisoner of war in North Vietnam. His daughter Lorrie, foreground, is followed by the other children, Robert, Cynthia and Roger, and his wife, Loretta.

item.title: AI and Hiring - What's the Deal
item.description: Our new series takes on the biggest questions about work, from resumes to AI.

item.title: Why Does Trump, the ‘America First’ President, Keep Looking to Foreign Leaders?
item.description: Trump keeps showing he is not as isolationist as many supporters had hoped.
item.dc:creator: Jess Bidgood and David E. Sanger

media:content.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump welcomed Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia to the White House on Tuesday.

item.title: Yann LeCun, a Pioneering A.I. Scientist, Leaves Meta
item.description: Dr. LeCun’s departure follows a shake-up in Meta’s artificial intelligence efforts, as Mark Zuckerberg pushes his company to keep up in the tech race.
item.dc:creator: Eli Tan

media:content.media:credit: Victor Llorente for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Despite Meta’s efforts to reach A.I. “superintelligence,” Yann LeCun has said that large language models will never be smart enough to be considered superintelligent.

item.title: Are These Buzzy New N.Y.C. Restaurants Worth a Visit?
item.description: This fall, The Times’s Food contributor Luke Fortney checked in on three of New York City’s biggest restaurant openings, all a few blocks apart in the West Village.

media:content.media:credit: Heather Willensky for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: What to get, besides the always excellent fries, at the Frenchette team’s latest restaurant.

item.title: Justin Bieber Got Some Grammys Respect (But Not Enough)
item.description: Will Justin Bieber finally get the institutional respect he’s been chasing at the Grammys? Jon Caramanica and Joe Coscarelli discuss why “SWAG” and “Daisies” aren’t getting all the flowers they deserve.
item.dc:creator: Popcast

item.title: Pumpkin Cheesecake
item.description: This dessert delivers all the warm spices of pumpkin pie along with the tangy creaminess of cheesecake.
item.dc:creator: Nyt Cooking

media:content.media:credit: Yossy Arefi for The New York Times (Photography and Styling)

item.title: Newly Discovered Bach Pieces Are the Fruits of Decades of Detective Work
item.description: A pair of organ works that scholars believe were written by a teenage Johann Sebastian Bach were premiered in Leipzig this week and added to the composer’s official catalog.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nagourney

media:content.media:credit: Jens Schlueter/Agence France-Presse, via Bach Archive/AFP Via Getty Image
media:content.media:description: The two pieces were premiered by Ton Koopman and given their own numbers in the catalog of Bach’s works: BWV 1178 and BWV 1179.

item.title: F.B.I. Hunt Intensifies for Ryan Wedding, Snowboarder Accused of Being a Drug Kingpin
item.description: Ryan Wedding, a former Olympic athlete said to be a major cocaine trafficker, is accused of ordering the murder of a witness who was set to testify against him.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai

media:content.media:credit: Adam Pretty/Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Ryan Wedding during the Salt Lake City Winter Olympics in 2002.

item.title: Honeyed Cranberries With Tahini
item.description: Cranberries are one of the few fruits that are almost exclusively eaten cooked, and it’s because of their natural pectin: Once the cranberries hit heat with sugar (or in this case, honey), they break down and set up into that familiar jammy sauce.
item.dc:creator: Nyt Cooking

media:content.media:credit: Bobbi Lin for The New York Times

item.title: Police Found $1 Million in a Tub Under a Garage. The Government Gets to Keep It.
item.description: A court ruled that the hidden cash, which the police found while searching for an illegal gun in Ontario, did not lawfully belong to the man living on the property.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson

media:content.media:credit: Ontario Superior Court of Justice
media:content.media:description: Some of the money recovered from Marcel Breton’s home in Thunder Bay, Ontario, in 2009. The police were searching for an illegal handgun when they found large amounts of cash hidden around the property.

item.title: Crispy Ginger Sticky Rice
item.description: Inspired by a Chinese classic that translates to “flavorful rice,” this dish lives up to the name. Chewy sticky rice has a natural faint sweetness, and here it goes savory with bacon and mushrooms.
item.dc:creator: Nyt Cooking

media:content.media:credit: Linda Xiao for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Samantha Seneviratne.

item.title: Rusia lanza un misil a Ucrania. Hay al menos 25 personas muertas
item.description: Mientras el presidente Volodímir Zelenski intenta reanimar las conversaciones de paz, el país sufre una oleada de ataques generalizados.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova, Eric Schmitt and Andrew E. Kramer

media:content.media:credit: Andriy Bodak/Reuters
media:content.media:description: Rescue workers at a residential building in Ternopil, Ukraine, on Wednesday. Such deadly attacks are relatively rare in the west of the country.

item.title: U.S.-Russian Peace Plan Would Force Ukraine to Cede Land and Cut Army
item.description: The 28-point proposal, which comes as the Trump administration tries to restart settlement talks, includes demands long rejected by Kyiv as nonstarters.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Maria Varenikova

media:content.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A Ukrainian artillery unit firing a howitzer at Russian targets in the Dnipropetrovsk region, last month.

item.title: Saudi Arabia’s Prince Has Big Plans, but His Giant Fund Is Low on Cash
item.description: After nearly a decade of expensive, hit-and-miss investments, Mohammed bin Salman is overseeing a behind-the-scenes restructuring of the kingdom’s all-important wealth fund.
item.dc:creator: Rob Copeland and Vivian Nereim

media:content.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump welcomed Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia to the White House on Tuesday.

item.title: The World Craves A.I. Chips
item.description: Also, a corruption scandal is roiling Ukraine. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Jensen Huang at the Nvidia GTC conference last month.

item.title: Mamdani and Tisch Agreed to Work Together. Here’s Where They Differ.
item.description: The New York City mayor-to-be, Zohran Mamdani, and the head of the Police Department, Jessica Tisch, have gaps to bridge on crime and policing.
item.dc:creator: Chelsia Rose Marcius and Maia Coleman

media:content.media:credit: Richard Drew/Associated Press
media:content.media:description: “Do the mayor-elect and I agree on everything? No, we don’t,” Commissioner Jessica Tisch wrote in an email to officers.

item.title: Stalled Contempt Inquiry Into Deportation Flights Springs Back to Life
item.description: The resurrected inquiry could finally get to the bottom of lingering questions such as: Did top Trump administration officials purposely ignore a court order?
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer

media:content.media:credit: Saul Loeb/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Judge James E. Boasberg’s initial order laying out the contempt investigation outlined an aggressive process for figuring out what happened inside the administration.

item.title: Appeals Court Blocks Limits on Federal Agents’ Use of Force in Chicago Area
item.description: A judge found that immigration agents were using force in a way that “shocks the conscience.” Appellate judges said the restrictions she imposed went too far.
item.dc:creator: Mitch Smith

media:content.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Federal agents deployed tear gas in Chicago last month.

item.title: Los aranceles globales de Trump afectaron al comercio, según datos
item.description: Los elevados aranceles que el presidente Trump impuso en agosto provocaron una contracción de las importaciones y del déficit comercial, según información divulgada recientemente.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson

item.title: Believe It or Not, That $12 Million Gold Toilet Was Bought by … Ripley’s
item.description: The entertainment company plans on displaying the toilet, saying its team is exploring “whether visitors may someday be allowed to use it.”
item.dc:creator: Zachary Small

media:content.media:credit: OK McCausland for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Ripley’s Believe It or Not, which paid $12.1 million for the toilet on Tuesday, said that “finding the unbelievable is our business.”

item.title: Mexico Is Now the United States’ Top Buyer
item.description: For first time in at least 30 years, the United States has exported more to Mexico than Canada, U.S. government data show, in a sign of how much North American trade has consolidated.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner

media:content.media:credit: Gabriel V. Cárdenas for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Trucks moving goods from the United States to Mexico in February. “Mexico is the United States’ main trading partner,” said Marcelo Ebrard, Mexico’s economy minister.

item.title: Holiday Gift Ideas: What to Get an Ex, a Sick Parent and More Recommendations
item.description: Plus: what to get a sick mother, a minimalist son and more holiday present advice from T Magazine.

item.title: Nvidia Earnings Show Profit Jumped 65% to $31.9 Billion
item.description: The company, which makes the computer chips essential to the artificial intelligence boom, also said revenue in its recent quarter rose to $57 billion.
item.dc:creator: Tripp Mickle

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Jensen Huang, the chief executive of Nvidia, made a bet on chips for artificial intelligence that has turned his company into a Silicon Valley giant.
